sp.p: Now things falling out as they do, you must leave these fond fond affections, nature will have it so, necessity must.

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: I will never love any but Phillida, her love is engraven in my heart, with her eyes.

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: Nor I any but Galathea, whose faith is imprinted in my thoughts by her words.

sp.speaker: Neptune
sp.p: An idle choice, strange, and foolish, for one virgin to dote on another, and to imagine a constant faith, where there can be no cause of affection. How like you this Venus?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: I like well and allow it, they shall both be possessed of their wishes, for never shall it be said that nature or fortune shall overthrow love, and faith. Is your love's unspotted, begun with truth, continued with constancy, and not to be altered till death?

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: Die Galathea if thy love be not so.

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p:
Accursed be thou Phillida if thy love be
not so.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Suppose all this Venus, what then?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then shall it be seen, that I can turn one of them to be a man, and that I will.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: What is to love or the mistress of love unpossible? Was it not Venus that did the like to Iphis and Ianthe; how say ye are ye agreed, one to be a boy presently?

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: I am content, so I may embrace Galathea.

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: I wish it, so I may enjoy Phillida.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Soft daughter, you must know whether I will have you a son.

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Take me with you Galathea, I will keep you as I begat you, a daughter.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Tityrus, let yours be a boy and if you will, mine shall not.

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Nay mine shall not, for by that means my young son shall lose his inheritance.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Why then get him to be made a maiden and then there is nothing lost.

sp.speaker: Tyte.
sp.p: If there be such changing, I would Venus could make my wife a man.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Because she loves always to play with men.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Well you are both fond, therefore agree to this changing, or suffer your daughters to endure hard chance.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: How say you Tityrus, shall we refer it to Venus.

sp.speaker: Tyte.
sp.p: I am content, because she is a goddess.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Neptune you will not dislike it.

sp.speaker: Neptune
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Nor you Diana.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Cupid shall not.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then let us depart, neither of them shall know whose lot it shall be till they come to the church-door. One shall be, doth it suffice?

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: And satisfy us both, doth it not Galathea?

sp.speaker: Galla.
sp.p: Yes Phillida.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Come Robin, I am glad I have met with thee, for now we will make our father laugh at these tales.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: What are these that so malepartlie thrust themselves into our companies?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Forsooth madam we are fortune tellers.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Fortune tellers; tell me my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: We do not mean fortune tellers, we mean fortune tellers: we can tell what fortune we have had these twelve months in the woods.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Let them alone, they be but peevish.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Yet they will be as good as minstrels at the marriage, to make us all merry.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I ladies we bear a very good consort,

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Can you sing?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Basely.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: And you?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Meanly.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: And what can you do?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: If they double it, I will treble it.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then shall ye go with us, and sing Hymen before the marriage. Are you content?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Content? never better content, for there we shall be sure to fill our bellies with capons rumps, or some such dainty dishes.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then follow us.

sp.speaker: Galla.
sp.p: Go all, 'tis I only that conclude all. You ladies may see, that Venus can make constancy fickleness, courage cowardice, modesty lightness, working things impossible in your sex, and tempering hardest heart's like softest wool. Yield ladies, yield to love ladies, which lurketh under your eyelids whilst you sleep, and playeth with your heart strings whilst you wake: whose sweetness never breedeth satiety, labour weariness, nor grief bitterness. Cupid was begotten in a mist, nursed in clouds, and sucking only upon conceits. Confess him a conqueror, whom ye ought to regard, sith it is unpossible to resist, for this is infallible, that love conquereth all things but itself, and ladies all hearts but their own.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
